ANG.dr_note: Patient needs regular therapy to manage anger. If anger causes conflict, a weekly visit is recommended until stable.
what_you_can_do: When anger rises, try taking a few slow, deep breaths—it can help your body calm down.
It’s okay to step away for a few minutes to give yourself space to breathe and reset.
Writing down what upset you might help you understand your feelings better.
Calming music or a simple breathing exercise might help soothe your mind and body.
what_your_family_can_do: Giving you a little space when emotions are high can feel really supportive.
Speaking gently and softly can help everyone feel safer.
Just listening without trying to fix or judge can mean a lot.
Avoiding blame or raised voices helps keep things from escalating.
what_to_eat: Nourishing foods like leafy greens, nuts, and fresh fruit can support a calmer mood.
You might feel better avoiding sugary snacks, energy drinks, or too much caffeine.
Staying hydrated with water throughout the day can help your body feel more balanced.
Foods rich in Omega-3s like salmon, walnuts, or chia seeds may help support emotional well being.
how_to_move_your_body: A short walk or some light movement can help release built up tension.
Punching a pillow or doing a few jumping jacks might help you express energy safely.
Gentle stretching or a few minutes of yoga can bring your body back to calm.
Even 10–15 minutes of movement a day can make a difference in how you feel.
how_to_sleep_better: Going to bed around the same time each night helps your body settle into a rhythm.
Putting screens away an hour before bed can help your mind wind down.
Soft music, a breathing exercise, or a warm drink might help you relax into sleep.
Aim for 7–9 hours when you can rest is part of healing.
extra_support_tips: Feeling angry is completely human it’s what you do with it that matters.
An anger journal can help you notice patterns and care for yourself with more awareness.
If anger feels overwhelming, talking with a therapist can bring real relief and tools.
Practicing grounding or mindfulness even for a minute can help you feel more centered.

DIS.dr_note: Often linked to crossed limits/values. Watch for avoidance or withdrawal. Weekly or 2-week visit can help the patient feel safe.
what_you_can_do: Notice where you feel disgust in your body, and try breathing slowly through it.
Simply naming it “I’m feeling disgusted” can help you feel less swept away by it.
Taking a short break from what triggered you can give you space to return with more clarity.
Ask yourself: What value feels hurt? What small boundary might help me feel safer?
what_your_family_can_do: Using kind, respectful words instead of shaming—helps everyone feel seen.
Gently asking, “What do you need right now?” can be deeply supportive.
Offering practical help like opening a window or tidying up—can ease physical discomfort.
Staying calm and steady, even when things feel intense, creates safety.
what_to_eat: If your stomach feels unsettled, simple foods like toast, bananas, or rice might feel easier.
Sipping water or ginger tea can soothe your system gently.
For now, you might feel better avoiding strong smells or heavy, greasy foods.
As you feel ready, returning to balanced, nourishing meals can help you feel grounded again.
how_to_move_your_body: A few minutes outside or near an open window can help clear your mind.
Gentle neck or shoulder rolls might release tension held in your body.
Tidying a small space if it helps can give a sense of control and calm.
Long, slow exhales can signal to your nervous system that you’re safe.
how_to_sleep_better: Keeping your room cool, clean, and well-ventilated can support restful sleep.
A simple wind-down like a warm shower or quiet reading can prepare your mind for rest.
Avoiding big meals close to bedtime might help your body relax more easily.
If your thoughts won’t settle, writing them down and closing the notebook can feel like a release.
extra_support_tips: Disgust often shows us what matters deeply to us—it’s a signal, not a flaw.
If this feeling shows up often or feels overwhelming, exploring it with a therapist can bring clarity.
The 5-senses grounding technique (notice 5 things you see, 4 you feel, etc.) can bring you back to the present.
Setting even one small, kind boundary today is an act of self care.

FEA.dr_note: Needs steady therapy. A weekly visit is advised, especially if fear affects daily activities.
what_you_can_do: When fear shows up, slow, deep breaths can help your body feel safer.
Ground yourself by noticing 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste.
Writing down your fear and gently asking, “Is this thought helpful or true?” can bring perspective.
Facing fear doesn’t mean doing it all at once tiny steps, taken kindly, build courage over time.
what_your_family_can_do: Saying, “I’m here with you,” feels more supportive than “Don’t be scared.”
Helping create a calm, safe space physically and emotionally matters deeply.
Letting you share your fear without rushing to fix it shows real care.
Gentle encouragement without pressure helps you move at your own pace.
what_to_eat: Calming foods like bananas, oatmeal, or chamomile tea might help soothe your nerves.
Too much caffeine can amplify anxious feelings you might notice a difference if you reduce it.
Light, regular meals can help avoid that “nervous stomach” feeling.
Staying hydrated supports your whole system in staying steady.
how_to_move_your_body: Gentle movement like walking, stretching, or slow yoga can help regulate your nervous system.
Shaking your limbs gently (like a dog after a bath!) can release stored tension.
Mindful movement like tai chi or qigong invites calm into your body.
Pairing breath with movement—inhale as you reach, exhale as you fold can feel deeply grounding.
how_to_sleep_better: Making your bedroom feel cozy, safe, and quiet can invite rest.
Avoiding scary movies, news, or stressful conversations before bed protects your peace.
Calming sounds or a short breathing exercise might help you drift off more easily.
A consistent bedtime even on weekends helps your body trust that rest is coming.
extra_support_tips: Fear is a natural part of being human you don’t have to face it alone.
Therapy offers safe, proven ways to understand and work with fear and anxiety.
Every small step you take deserves kindness celebrate your courage, not just the outcome.
You are stronger than your fear, even on days when it doesn’t feel that way.

HAP.dr_note: Stable, positive mood. Keep healthy habits. Move to a 2-week or 4-week visit to maintain progress.
what_you_can_do: Savor this moment let yourself fully enjoy what’s bringing you joy right now.
Sharing your good feelings with someone you care about can deepen the warmth.
This is a great time to gently nurture healthy routines that support your well-being.
Jotting down what’s going well can help you remember these bright moments later.
what_your_family_can_do: Celebrating even small joys with you like a shared smile or laugh builds connection.
Joining you in something fun or relaxing shows you’re valued just as you are.
Enjoying simple, unhurried time together can strengthen your bond.
Supporting your healthy habits without pressure helps joy last longer.
what_to_eat: Balanced meals continue to fuel your energy and mood, even on good days.
Enjoying a treat in moderation is part of a joyful, balanced life you deserve it!
Bright fruits like berries or oranges add natural energy and color to your day.
Staying hydrated helps you feel your best, inside and out.
how_to_move_your_body: Dancing to a favorite song, playing outside, or tossing a ball can keep joy flowing.
Group activities like a walk with a friend or a dance class multiply the fun.
Moving your body, even lightly, helps sustain that feel good energy.
When movement feels like play, it’s easier to keep coming back to it.
how_to_sleep_better: Keeping your sleep schedule steady helps you wake up refreshed and ready for more good days.
A cozy wind-down like reading or soft music lets happiness settle into rest.
Limiting screens before bed helps your mind transition gently into sleep.
Good sleep isn’t just rest it’s how your body stores and renews joy.
extra_support_tips: Sharing your happiness can lift others too your light matters.
Use these calm, joyful moments to build inner strength for tougher days.
Practicing gratitude like listing 3 good things helps joy sink in deeper.
Even on happy days, checking in with yourself is a loving habit.

NEU.dr_note: May mean stable or holding back. If doing well, a 2-week visit is fine; if mood stays flat, use weekly visits.
what_you_can_do: Take a quiet moment to gently ask yourself: How am I really feeling beneath the calm?
Doing one small thing that feels meaningful like watering a plant or texting a friend can add warmth.
This peaceful space is a chance to reflect, dream, or plan something kind for yourself.
Sitting quietly with a cup of tea or just watching the sky can be enough.
what_your_family_can_do: Spending relaxed, low-pressure time together like sharing a meal builds quiet connection.
Asking open, gentle questions like, “How’s your heart today?” invites sharing without pressure.
Inviting you to join a calm activity like a walk or puzzle offers companionship without demand.
Keeping things light, warm, and supportive honors your current state.
what_to_eat: A warm, simple meal like soup or stew can feel comforting and nourishing.
Brain-supportive foods like eggs, greens, or fish help maintain steady energy.
Regular, balanced meals keep your foundation strong, even when emotions are quiet.
Sipping water throughout the day supports your overall well being.
how_to_move_your_body: A short walk—even without a goal can gently shift your energy.
A few minutes of stretching or rolling your shoulders might feel refreshing.
Tidying a drawer or watering plants turns small movement into care.
Letting your body move naturally without pressure can awaken subtle joy.
how_to_sleep_better: A consistent, calming bedtime routine signals safety to your nervous system.
Use this quiet time to truly rest and reset not just for sleep, but for your whole self.
If your mind is busy, soft music or a sleep story might help it settle.
Avoiding caffeine in the afternoon helps your body ease into rest more naturally.
extra_support_tips: Neutral isn’t empty it’s a valid, peaceful place to be. Not every day needs fireworks.
This calm is a gift use it to recharge, reflect, or simply be.
Trying a quiet hobby like coloring, knitting, or listening to music can feel soothing.
Balance includes stillness. Honor this peace as part of your emotional rhythm.

SAD.dr_note: If sadness lasts or the patient withdraws, regular support is needed. A weekly visit is recommended to improve mood and prevent decline.
what_you_can_do: On hard days, just getting out of bed is a victory. Be gentle with yourself.
Sharing how you feel with someone safe can lighten the weight, even a little.
Writing in a journal without editing or judging lets your heart speak.
Even 10 minutes of sunlight or fresh air can offer a small lift.
what_your_family_can_do: A quiet “How are you, really?” without pushing shows you care.
Sometimes just sitting together in silence, without trying to fix anything, is enough.
Inviting you to join a small, low effort activity like making tea offers connection without pressure.
Reminding them, “You’re not alone,” can be a lifeline.
what_to_eat: Warm, comforting meals with protein and veggies can gently support your energy.
Try to eat regularly even small amounts since skipping meals can deepen low mood.
Bananas, nuts, and whole grains offer steady fuel for your brain and body.
Drinking enough water is a simple but powerful way to care for yourself.
how_to_move_your_body: A slow walk around the block or some gentle stretches can help shift heaviness.
Dancing alone to one favorite song can reconnect you with your body and joy.
Light movement like yoga or chair exercises meets you where you are.
Five minutes of movement is still movement and it counts.
how_to_sleep_better: A calming bedtime routine like dim lights and soft music can ease you into rest.
Long daytime naps can make nighttime sleep harder—short rests are gentler.
A weighted blanket might offer a sense of comfort and safety as you sleep.
Gentle sleep sounds or a guided relaxation can help quiet a busy, sad mind.
extra_support_tips: Sadness can feel endless, but it won’t last forever—even when it seems like it will.
Asking for help isn’t weakness it’s one of the bravest things you can do.
Therapy or a support group offers understanding and tools when sadness feels heavy.
Celebrate tiny wins: getting dressed, drinking water, texting a friend they all matter.
